questions.title: Question 2
questions.text: What is the main finding in the OCT above?

answers.explanation: Pre-choroidal clefts are seen as a hypo-reflective cavity between Bruch’s membrane and hyper-reflective material in PEDs on OCT imaging. They can be seen in 8.1% - 22.3% of eyes treated for neovascular AMD and are thought to represent exudative fluid leakage from choroidal neovascularization fibrous membranes \[1,2]. The presence of a pre-choroidal cleft has been associated with poorer visual prognosis and type 3 CNV \[2,3].

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: What is the risk of treating these patients with anti-VEGF injections?

answers.explanation: A study by Mukai et al. in 2014 revealed that RPE tear can occur in up to 23% of patients with a pre-choroidal cleft \[1]. In patients treated with anti-VEGF agents, there was a greater incidence of RPE tear in eyes with pre-choroidal clefts than in eyes without \[2]. Mechanisms of the tear are thought to involve contraction of the choroidal neovascularization membranes resulting in tensile forces that tear at edges of the detached RPE \[4] Thus, close monitoring of eyes with neovascular AMD is recommended to detect development of these clefts, and patients should be counselled on the risk of complications following anti-VEGF treatment such as RPE tears.

title: Case 74
patientPresentation:
A 78-year-old man was referred to a tertiary retina clinic for decreased vision OS. The patient denied red eye, flashes, floaters, scalp tenderness, or jaw claudication. He had a 40-pack year smoking history. Ocular history was significant for cataract extraction OU and dry AMD, which was monitored by his optometrist.

His visual acuity was 20/25 OD and 20/100 OS. There was no RAPD. IOP was within normal limits. Anterior segment examination was unremarkable. Fundus examination demonstrated numerous medium – large sized drusen OU with no sign of hemorrhage.
